title: Fix for nebraska scraping
body:
As i mentioned in issue #1452 the problem with nebraska opinion files is that they are updating them causing the timestamp to be updated in pdf, causing the generated sha to not match the one stored in CL opinions.

The solution I propose is really simple, they are updating the pdf files but the download url is still the same, for example, this opinion https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/6905720/schaaf-v-schaaf/ is duplicated 26 times, the first timestamp is from 07/22/2022 09:05 AM CDT and the last is from 10/14/2022 09:07 AM CDT but the download url is always the same: https://www.nebraska.gov/apps-courts-epub/public/viewOpinion?docId=N00008736PUB

What makes this fix is that when the scrapper for Nebraska is run, it will use the download_url as the lookup field instead of sha field which can easily change even if they just update the timestamp.

This is really simple, but does the job, and in case of having a similar situation to the one with nebraska, we just need to add the court_str to the exception list.

title: Avoid add citations in incorrect cases
body:
After @flooie started to import the missing volumes from Federal Appendix reporter (F. App'x) we noticed that some citations were added to incorrect cases, these are two examples:

https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/622150/united-states-v-truman-scott/ correct citation is 463 F. App'x 227

https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/622149/united-states-v-frank-esquivel/ correct citation is 463 F. App'x 226

We have many functions to check if two cases are the same, and after digging in the process of Harvard imported, I realized that the problem might be when we try to check if there is an overlap in the case names which causes to return the incorrect case as has previously been imported, and this case to add the incorrect citation.

This is a way to reproduce the problem:

First, we remove the incorrect citation from (I did this in my local env) https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/622149/united-states-v-frank-esquivel/

Then we try to import this case: https://ia801003.us.archive.org/21/items/law.free.cap.f-appx.463/225.4117247.json which is the one with the correct citation: 463 F. App'x 225

The script searches for possible cases, and because we deleted the incorrect citation the first check fails, then we try again to search for possible cases again, but this time we use the court and the date filed as filter params and then we get some matches, “United States v. Frank Esquivel” is in the matches.

Then we start to perform some comparisons to see if the case to import is the same as the ones of the results we got previously. All the checks says that the case is the same.

But I believe the problem is in one of the checks, specifically in this function case_names_dont_overlap (https://github.com/freelawproject/courtlistener/blob/main/cl/corpus_importer/management/commands/harvard_opinions.py#L754)

We need that this function returns a True value to say that there is no overlapping between the case names we are comparing. And having a True value will let us say that the cases are not the same, break the condition and avoid adding the citation to incorrect case. You can see more about this here: (https://github.com/freelawproject/courtlistener/blob/main/cl/corpus_importer/management/commands/harvard_opinions.py#L854)

Here is an example of what is causing the failure, we compare these two case names to check if there is an overlap:

“United States v. Frank Esquivel” and “United States v. Vinson UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee, v. Wayne VINSON, Defendant-Appellant”

As you can see, there is an overlap only with “united” and “states” (some words are removed due the use of harmonize function to juriscraper and other processes), the problem here is that in this specific case “united states” doesn’t have the enough relevance for us to say that both cases are the same, what difference these two cases is the other party. 

One way to solve this is to remove that kind of strings in the check what can cause this unexpected behavior.

This PR removes the string “united states” in that specific check to avoid an overlap with case names that include that string.

But why this happened?

It happened that two consequential cases in the same volume had the same decision date, court, and very similar names: “United States v. Vinson (463 F. App'x 225)”, “United States v. Frank Esquivel (463 F. App'x 226)” and “United States v. Scott (463 F. App'x 227)”

This caused to have many potential possible cases and similar names, and this caused an overlap in the names, making the script to return the case to add the citation instead to jump to verify next case.

Another way to fix this would be also adjusting or improving the other functions that makes the checks, for example cosine_similarity_too_different() which checks if the case names are the same using a different approach, we could apply something similar of what i suggest above.

Currently i'm checking how valid would be to modify the other functions that performs the comparison between case, for example the function that compare the length of content between cases (length_too_different function) and the function that checks the similarity between the content of the cases (content_too_different function)

title: Keep acronyms/abbreviations in case name when searching for duplicates in Harvard opinion importer
body:
Fix for issue #2204 

With this fix, abbreviations/acronyms won't be removed from case name when searching for case names overlapping.

The problem happens when you have a case name that only contains acronyms/abbreviations, like: “D.L.M. v. T.J.S.”

The current regexes used to find the name overlapping removes the acronyms/abbreviations, in the example above causes to wipe the full string causing duplicates with that type of case names.

With the new regex added, now the acronyms/abbreviations are kept, "D.L.M" turns into "DLM", "U.S." turns into "US", etc.

title: Harvard Opinions Import duplicates with some case names
body:
Working in #2191  issue, I found a possible bug that could cause duplicate cases with case names contianing only abbreviations or acronyms.

How did I come to that conclusion?

When analyzing the code to find the bug in #2191  issue, I decided to remove the check that if the opinion is already on the system based on Harvard opinion JSON path.  Here: https://github.com/freelawproject/courtlistener/blob/ed59ae5fe2b192d51f86a96e49d8ce38540587f4/cl/corpus_importer/management/commands/harvard_opinions.py#L290

After I removed that, I ran the importer with the cases from “law.free.cap.sw3d.134” from the first time with no problem. And then I ran it again and found that the only case that has been duplicated was “134 S.W.3d 673”. Tried again and again and still creates duplicates.

I started digging into that issue and I found that the problem lies specifically with the winnow_case_name function here: https://github.com/freelawproject/courtlistener/blob/ed59ae5fe2b192d51f86a96e49d8ce38540587f4/cl/corpus_importer/management/commands/harvard_opinions.py#L944

Which is called in the function case_names_dont_overlap, this function is used to check that case names do not overlap, it returns True if there is no overlap between two sets of words and false in otherwise.

This function uses the shortened case name from OpinionCluster found in possible cases, uses the full case name from Harvard opinion JSON and the case name abbreviation from Harvard opinion JSON.

Basically, winnow_case_name function reduces a title case to a set of words to compare in case_names_dont_overlap function.
To reduce the case names with the function, the name is converter to lowercase, then runs a first regex that removes chars like dots and at the end a regex removes one-letter words, initials, etc.

The problem happens when there’s a case name like “D.L.M. v. T.J.S.” because the process removes everything, leaving an empty string, causing a malfunction that leads to creating duplicates with this type of case names.

For example, we have the full case name from Harvard “Appeal of HAMILTON & CHAMBERS CO., INC.” and the case name abbreviation: “Appeal of Hamilton & Chambers Co.”, and the shortened name from the case in OpinionCluster: “Appeal of Hamilton & Chambers Co.”
There’s a function that reduces each case title to a set of words (in winnow_case_name function).
You pass the shortened case name from the opinion cluster to the function, and you get:
{'co', 'chambers', 'hamilton', 'appeal'}

Then you pass the Harvard case name + the case name abbreviation, for these purposes, is: “Appeal of HAMILTON & CHAMBERS CO., INC. Appeal of Hamilton & Chambers Co.”

The winnow_case_name function outputs: {'chambers', 'co', 'hamilton', 'appeal'}

If you perform and & operation between both dict of course there’s an overlap, so the case_names_dont_overlap returns a False

But what happen when you have a full case name from Harvard: “In the matter of S.J.S., a minor child. D.L.M. and D.E.M., Petitioners/Respondents v. T.J.S.”, a case name abbreviation: “D.L.M. v. T.J.S.” and the shortened OpinionCluster name: “D.L.M. v. T.J.S.”

Then you pass “D.L.M. v. T.J.S.” to the function that reduces the title to a set of words, and as result you get an empty set because of one of the regex.

And if you pass “In the matter of S.J.S., a minor child. D.L.M. and D.E.M., Petitioners/Respondents v. T.J.S. D.L.M. v. T.J.S.” to the function, you get: {'respondents', 'minor', 'child', 'petitioners'}

The regex removed the important stuff, I think.

So, when you compare both sets of words, of course there’s no overlap, because one set is empty and the other only have a few words.

After this, the case_names_dont_overlap function returns a True so ignore the possible case that it’s already on courtlistener, and then return a None because couldn’t find the case even if it’s in the system.

title: Opinions by Judges links only to CL, not RECAP
body:
For a District Court judge, e.g., [Alsup](https://www.courtlistener.com/person/89/william-haskell-alsup/), the link at the bottom "[Search for All Opinions Authored by Alsup](https://www.courtlistener.com/?type=o&q=author_id%3A89+OR+panel_ids%3A89)" links out to a page of that judge's opinions in the CL database. (125 at the time of this issue filing). 

But if we go to the RECAP archive tab and search for cases "Assigned to" and enter "Alsup" we'll get [5,528 cases](https://www.courtlistener.com/?type=r&q=&type=r&order_by=score%20desc&assigned_to=Alsup) that are in RECAP, the vast majority of which one assumes he authored one or more opinions in.

Until everything is in a single database to rule them all, I suggest the Judge page, for federal judges, needs two links:

1. "Search for All Opinions Authored by Alsup in CourtListener" (existing link)
2. "Search for All Cases Assigned to Alsup in RECAP" (new proposed link)

While this is sort of an enhancement / feature request, I think the phrase "for All Opinions" makes this more of a bug because it is so misleading for users, who might not realize they're missing thousands of cases by not searching in the RECAP tab.

title: Financial Disclosures Search Unexpected Behavior
body:
When you enter or copy paste a judge into the financial disclosures without results and hit enter, it does a search

`https://www.courtlistener.com/?disclosures-filter=random-judge-input`

It throws it into an opinions search.  This is weird and unexpected behavior.  Its also probably pretty confusing for users.

title: Tenn. Workers Comp Uploader failing
body:
Tenn. Uploader failed to generate citations (silently) because we did not match the citation generated to our new 
citation/parallel_citaiton world view.

title: Date mismatch between search results page and opinion page
body: If one does a search on CourtListener that brings up the non-precedential Kihn v. Bill Graham Archives (9th Cir.) opinion issued on January 3, 2022, then the search results page will show it as "Date Filed: January 2nd, 2022" but once you click on the link and get to the opinion page one sees it reported as "Filed: January 3rd, 2022" (which is correct, or which at least matches the PDF from the court). Why would the search results page provide a different filing date? Are there other instances of this sort of mismatch? Is the opinion page always correct or is sometimes the search results page correct and the opinion page wrong? Are we translating time zones from UTC or something in different ways in different places?

title: Added message for ValueError exception
body:
Adds exception message to handle **ValueError** exception in task `get_and_save_free_document_report` and command `get_and_save_free_document_reports`.
Also, adds a default mesage for any othe exceptions in `get_and_save_free_document_reports`.

Closes: freelawproject/juriscraper#418

title: Added exception when PACER free opinion scraper fails when response is invalid HTML page
body:
Added exceptions to handle when PACER free opinion scraper fails due to server response returning an invalid HTML page or other type of document.
Some court's servers block requests to scrap opinion documents. But if the returned page is not a proper HTML page, the parse fails and this error wasn't properly cought and logged.

Closes: freelawproject/juriscraper#418

body: We failed to account for every situation in building out disclosure Positions and are using the people_db.Positions API in certain circumstances.

body: This (should) resolve the build issue created by merging #1671.

title: Nebraska Scraping Fail
body:
[307 Neb 1 over and over](https://www.courtlistener.com/c/Neb./307/1/)

I stumbled onto a duplicating opinion bug that is repeatedly allowing cases to be collected over and over and over again.  The case above has been scraped and added to our system 21 times as of 11/9/20 at 3:22 PM EST.

title: Opinions without docket numbers cant display docket page
body:
I'm not sure how widespread this issue is, but opinions without docket numbers can not display the docket page because of the following example bug and code. 

https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/2520846/commonwealth-v-hadley/


The core_docket_data code fails in cl/opinion_page/views.py because s.strip() fails when None is passed in.  
```
def core_docket_data(request, pk):
    """Gather the core data for a docket, party, or IDB page."""
    docket = get_object_or_404(Docket, pk=pk)
    title = ", ".join(
        [
            s
            for s in [
                trunc(best_case_name(docket), 100, ellipsis="..."),
                docket.docket_number,
            ]
            if s.strip()
        ]
    )```

title: Fix large docket numbers
body: Adds workaround to large docket numbers.  Adds docket numbers to Corrections field if too large for database model (unique together)

title: Difference between expected and actual for harvard imports
body:
We are two cases short from expected imports in B.T.A. (1 case is understood).

We have ~ 40 case difference between expected and actual for T.C.

title: Bulk data contains invalid API urls
body:
The bulk data for opinions (e.g. [ca1](https://www.courtlistener.com/api/bulk-data/opinions/ca1.tar.gz)) contains the invalid resource URLs (port 80 vs https):

```
{
  "resource_uri": "https://www.courtlistener.com:80/api/rest/v3/opinions/11/",
  "id": 11,
  "absolute_url": "/opinion/11/cianbro-corp-v-george-h-dean-inc/",
  "cluster": "https://www.courtlistener.com:80/api/rest/v3/clusters/11/",
  "author": null,
  "joined_by": [],
```

title: Dockets can become unblocked
body:
I'm not entirely sure how this is happening without digging into the code, but I am reasonably sure that dockets occasionally become unblocked. I think the issue is:

1. We get a docket, it's public.
1. We get a removal request, we abide, it's now private.
1. We get an update to the docket, it become public again.

Pretty sure that's how it's going. Will check once larger projects are settled a bit.

title: Word boundary character needed to precede regex strings
Clusters with multiple opinions should only occur once in search results
body: As of now, if a cluster has multiple opinions, the case shows up multiple times in search results. It should only show up once.

title: Solr results need to be udpated to handle multiple opinions per cluster
body:
We moved the per_curiam field to Opinion objects instead of Cluster objects, which is mostly fine, but that makes it into a Solr field that should have `multiValued=True`, which it presently does not.

To fix this, I've commented out the field in search_indexes.py. This is a bad fix, but since the field has almost no data anyway, it's OK not to pass that (absence of) data to Solr.

The correct fix is to add a for loop to search_indexes.py so that all of the opinion objects are iterated over (this will parallel how we do this for several objects in the Person search). We'll also have to do some work on the front end to make the results be cluster oriented but with opinions-based results. Something like:

> ## Apple v. FBI
> 
> Metadata: Blah, Metadatab:bar
> ### Two Opinions:
> 
> > Concurrence
> > ...snippet text...blah blah...some more stuff...
> > Dissent
> > ...snippet text...blah blah...some more stuff...

This will require that we do grouping on Solr results. Somewhere I have research indicating this is possible and fairly simple, but I'll have to delve into my emails and whatnot to figure it out again (not that it's so complex).

title: Court.postion should not allow null values
body: Why would we ever allow null values? This is a simple fix, but it requires going back through fixtures and fixing them as well, which can take time.

I changed my email address within the CL profile page.
It logged me out and says I cannot log back in without confirming the new address. (Query whether this is wise...)
Email is either taking forever or is not being generated at all.
I'm now locked out of my account.

Seems like we need 1) a fix for the email situation; 2) a better flow that, at a minimum, gives people a chance to request the confirmation email again.

title: Case cites itself

This case cites itself in "cited by":

https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/784253/johann-breyer-v-john-ashcroft-us-immigration-and-n/

title: opinions-cited API backend creates horrible, evil query
body:
Somehow this API endpoint thinks it's OK to do a SELECT statement without a where clause. Doesn't it know that this will pull about 10GB into memory from the database? 

I threatened to nuke this endpoint on the dev email list, but I was pleased to get it put together. Until now.

title: Populating the case_name_full field has nuked the slug field and made the site lack case names
body:
In the new system, we've migrated any case name that's longer than 150 chars into the `case_name_full` field. In general, these are the ridiculous case names from PRO, and the idea was to move them aside so that we can start dealing with the issue. 

Naturally, this has caused issues because in the past we've always assumed that every case would have a value in the `ccase_name` field, and for these 88135 cases, that's not true anymore. 

So:
- Wherever we've previously assumed that we'd have a value in the `case_name` field, we need to make it fall back to `case_name_full`. For example, on the authorities page we count on having a value in `case_name`. When we don't, we just show nothing, which winds up looking like:
  
  > , 23 U.S. 332
  
  Terrible.
- For these cases, they do not have a slug because the slug creator assumes that there's a value for `case_name`. Without the value you get no slug. We need to make slugs for these cases using `case_name_full`.
- There are 283 SCOTUS cases that lack `case_name` values. It's probably worth it to go through these and fix them. Overall, there are 88135 items with this problem -- too many to fix, except by crowdsourcing or something. [Here's a CSV that needs some love](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ii0nx9jfy63y4j6/long_names.csv?dl=0).

title: Update TOS for CourtListener to remove address
body:
Since we're no longer with Berkeley, don't want to pay and deal with a PO Box, and can't be giving out our home addresses, I've removed all physical addresses from CourtListener. There are two remaining places where a physical address was called for:
1. On the donate page, where people can send checks (I've updated this so people can ask us for our address, if they want it, so that's taken care of).
2. In the TOS, where we tell people we only accept removal requests in writing. 

Number 2 needs to be fixed by releasing a new version of the TOS without that language, and by archiving the previous version, as we usually do.

I'm assuming there's no legal reason why we ask for stuff in writing. @brianwc, please correct me here if I'm wrong.

title: Hit list for pushing new version live
body:
This will be an ongoing ticket so people can see what's left before the big upgrade. Still lots to do, but it's getting close.

Pre-launch:
- [x] Answer infrastructure questions:
  - What server will host the new installation? A: The new one.
  - Is now the time to move celery to its own server and to move it to reddis? A: Yep.
  - Do we have enough disk space? A: On the new server, sure.
  - How does virtualenv work with apache?
- [x] Make the migration script resumable and address all the TODOs it has in its comments.
- [x] Finish updating scrapers
- [x] Finish updating search
- [x] Work through any other TODO comments that are identified by Intellij
- [x] Tweak Apache, Solr, Postgres settings for max performance and to mirror old CL.
- [x] Finish API
- [x] Mail server junk:
  - [x] Server name
  - [x] Any nasty signatures or whatever?
- [x] Issue #416 is a blocker, alas.

Launch:
- [x] Get latest code into `/var/www/cl/`
- [x] Complete the applicable parts of the CL installation:
  - [x] Create virtualenv and fill it with requirements.txt
  - [x] Create a new database called cl
  - [x] ...?
- [x] Disable any cron job that'll modify data
- [x] Put the regular site in maintenance mode so the data is stable
- [x] Run manage.py mega_migrate
- [x] Update proxy config to point to old server in smarter way (it currently uses courtlistener.com, which will summarily break when the new server goes live).
- [x] Run the citation finder!
- [x] Issue #380 (to fix slug links -- easier to fix this after the migration has run)

Post launch:
- [x] Enable the cron jobs for scrapers and other processes
- [x] Regenerate citegeist scores, and note speed

title: Lawbox import problem
body:
Here is an example:

https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2051624/cooper-v-state/

This document has data in the html_lawbox field but nothing in the html_with_citations field. Consequently the displayed version on the site has no citation hyperlinks. It seems like some part of the lawbox import must have had a problem. Oh, and this is not an isolated example. I'm fairly sure there are thousands. It's unclear whether simply running the citation finder anew would resolve this. Instead it seems like the citation finder could have a bug with respect to certain lawbox docs.

title: 'Min Cites' filter causes "deadly error"
body:
1. Enter a search query. Example 'copyright'.
2. On the results page, enter a number in the 'Min Cites' box, such as '5' and click search.
3. Deadly error results.

title: Contact Form is not DMARC Compliant; Rejecting mail
body:
When Yahoo! and a few others changed their DMARC policies last year it also broke web forms all over the internet. If someone types their yahoo.com email address into the CL contact form, then since we deliver it to courtlistener email addresses hosted by Google, Google respects Yahoo's DMARC policy and rejects the mail because it did not actually originate from yahoo.com. Same goes for Comcast and AOL email addresses. So, we've been silently (from our perspective) rejecting many contacts. The sender gets an undelivered mail message, but would have to be persistent to figure out how to tell us about it. There are apparently a few settings we can tweak in our form that will fix this.

Relevant details are here: http://www.fastsecurecontactform.com/yahoo-com-dmarc-policy

Example Undelivered Mail Returned to Sender response (with email addresses snipped):
_Subject:_ Undelivered Mail Returned to Sender

----- Forwarded Message -----

title: Bulk Data isn't Updating the Citation CSV

milestone.title: Redcard
milestone.description: Items that simply cannot wait. Other work should be set aside and this work should be completed immediately.

body:
I'm not sure why this is. The code uses `os.system()` to do a `psql` call. It gets nasty with various backslashes and such, but it worked fine when I tried to do it on the system. 

Probably a permissions or other error. Could also be that this command is run after the rest of the bulk data is created, and something could be crashing as part of that. Not entirely sure atm.

title: Podcast icon not rendering on alerts page
body:
See screenshot. Some sort of podcast icon or similar button is not rendering and exposing raw HTML on the profile/alerts/ page. (Alert text has been redacted from screenshot.)

![screenshot from cl](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/324921/5929027/e7ef5ca6-a634-11e4-85a6-9025b716553a.png)

title: hashchange is now supported in enough browsers; globally remove shim
body:
Easy bug, but needs testing and I don't want to forget to do it. Easy performance improvement and platform simplification.

@jraller, if you want this one, grab it, else, I'll get to it soon.

title: OA's from data donation have scrambled meta data
body:
Somehow the CSV that we ended up using got scrambled so the audio downloaded doesn't line up with the meta data in the database. This is pretty bad and reminds me of my dislike of Spreadsheets (also how rusty I am with them).

I'll be fixing this over the next hour or two:
- [x] All basic meta data needs to be fixed in the DB and updated in Solr (duration, case name, court, etc.)
- [x] Files need to be moved to the correct locations on disk (they're in date-based directories and the dates are about to change) and renamed (the files have the case-name for their file name).
- [x] id3 data needs to be updated (includes new album art, album name, comments, etc.)
- [x] Associated dockets need to be fixed (they have jurisdiction info, case name, etc.)

Most of this will be pretty easy. Just have to be very careful not to make any mistakes. As this runs, we'll surely have duplicates, but I can mitigate the front end weirdness by doing a single commit at the end.

title: Hyperlinks not being added to opinion text
body:
See, for example, https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/625710/mayo-collaborative-services-v-prometheus-laborator/

The TOA shows that we know this opinion cites at least 11 other opinions, but the only hyperlink we created was for the O'Reilly v. Morse case. No hyperlinks are present for the 10 other opinions we know it cites (and that's ignoring any cites we may have missed).

We could identify the scope of this problem by, for each document, doing a count of the opinion_ids in the cases_cited field and then counting how many instances of "href" occur in the html_with_citations field. They ought to be equal. If a document comes back with fewer "href"s in html_with_citations than it has opinion_ids in cases_cited, then it is an example of this issue.

Here's another example: https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2679558/alice-corp-v-cls-bank-intl/ The TOA shows we know about six citations within the document, but we only hyperlink one of them.

title: Supreme Court cases cited incorrectly in search results
body:
Example: Goldberg v. Kelly (SCOTUS 1970) 

The "SCOTUS" identifier shouldn't be there. This didn't used to happen, so some recent change made this rear its ugly head.

title: Oral Argument Alerts Being Sent Repeatedly
body: I set up an oral argument alert for 'klayman' and was notified of the oral argument audio on Tuesday, as expected. However, I received the identical alert yesterday and today, so have now been notified three times. I expect this will continue forever unless I intervene and worry that everyone's oral argument alerts are repeating like this.

title: Oral Arg Audio Doesn't Play on Android
body:
Not sure what's going on, but a file that I can play on Chrome on Mac OS X won't play on Chrome on Android (Nexus 5). https://www.courtlistener.com/audio/5/ajc-logistics-llc-v-triple-s-propiedad/ 

My Android browser is Chrome 38.0.2125.114
OS Android 4.4.4; Nexus 5 Build/KTU84P
JavaScript Version V8 3.28.71.15

title: Bulk API files appear to have the wrong dates
body:
A user has identified that the results in this query don't have the dates they expect:

> https://www.courtlistener.com/api/bulk/2014/08/04/all.xml.gz

I'm not sure if they're correct or not, because this could be a timezone thing. Their problem is that they expect data from 2014/08/04, but they're getting results for 2014/08/03.

title: Trying to edit alerts while logged out creates a 404, not a log in error
body:
A link like the following should suggest to the user that they need to log in:

> https://www.courtlistener.com/alert/edit/849/

Instead, it tells them that the page doesn't exist, which is false. I think a 403 is the usual error for this.

title: Items without dates in their body cannot be searched by West Citation

milestone.title: 1.0 - Law Librarian
milestone.description:
The next milestone of CourtListener will be 1.0. It's a file starting point. Naming it Law Librarian with the plan that versions can be named after people in the legal world in some form or other.

This version will land:

 - the docket-based database
 - the new API version
 - oral arguments from the federal circuit courts
 - any bug fixes that we are able to slip in

body:
This is a basic problem that we hadn't run into yet because most cases have their date directly in their body.

STR:
- Search for a complete West Citation like "[Wheaton v. Peters 33 U.S. 591 (1834)](https://www.courtlistener.com/?q=Wheaton+v.+Peters+33+U.S.+591+%281834%29&stat_Precedential=on&order_by=score+desc)"
- Because it's got 'v' in it, the case should be at the top. 
- Note that the case is nowhere in the results.

Unfortunately dates are not currently indexed, so the item gets excluded from the results. Removing "1834" from the query remedies the problem, putting the item at the top. 

The fix here is to add the date to search_index.py so it is indexed, and then do a reindex on all content.
